Adequate infrastructure and resources, such as recycling centers and composting facilities, may not be readily available.
Waste reduction efforts may be perceived as time-consuming or inconvenient, causing people to revert to their usual habits.
The financial costs of switching to zero waste practices may be perceived as prohibitive.
Zero waste practices may be perceived as “elitist” or only feasible for those with certain backgrounds or resources.
The lack of buy-in from those who can impact the movement, like local businesses and government officials.
